definitions.definition: the part of a person that makes them able to be aware of things, to think and to feel

examples.text: the **conscious/subconscious mind**
There were all kinds of thoughts running through my mind.
There was no doubt in his mind that he'd get the job.
‘Drugs’ are associated in most people's minds with drug abuse.
She was in a disturbed **state of mind**.
I could not have complete **peace of mind** before they returned.
The campaign to win the **hearts and minds** of the public continues.
I felt refreshed in **mind and body**.
Exhaustion clouded her mind.
It is a mecca for those seeking sustenance for the mind, body and spirit.
He had closed his mind to anything new.
Her mind was still reeling from the shock.
His comments did nothing to ease my mind.
I couldn't get my mind around the concept.
I need a clear mind if I want to continue with my work.
You've been in my mind a lot lately.
It was something she had never imagined, not even in the deepest recesses of her mind.
Kate desperately searched her mind for some excuse.
Our subconscious mind tries to protect us.
Serious doubts began to flood my mind.
She was poisoning his mind and turning him against his family.
There was absolutely no doubt in my mind that he was guilty.
Try meditating to clear your mind of negative thoughts.
the complex nature of the human mind
When you go to sleep it is only the conscious mind that shuts down.

phrases: at the back of your mind
in the back of your mind
at the forefront of your mind

definitions.definition: your ability to think and reason; your intelligence; the particular way that somebody thinks

examples.text: to have a brilliant/good/keen mind
a creative/evil/suspicious mind
She had a lively and enquiring mind.
His mind is as sharp as ever.
I've no idea how her mind works!
He had the body of a man and the mind of a child.
Their evidence might give us some insights into the criminal mind.
She has a brilliant mind.
to rouse the public mind to a sense of the dangers
In dreams we explore the hidden depths of the human mind.
I wish I had that type of creative mind.
He had probably the finest mind of the whole group.
Did you know you have a nasty suspicious mind?
He wanted us to focus our minds on unsolved problems.
impressionable young minds that are easily influenced
She was the only person who understood his mind.
You have to train your mind to think positively.
There 's no question in my mind that Kelly's pictures are better than Astaire's.

phrases: at the back of your mind
in the back of your mind
at the forefront of your mind

definitions.definition: a person who is very intelligent

examples.text: She was one of the greatest minds of her generation.
a problem that has defeated the world's finest minds
Larry is one of the best trained minds in the industry.

phrases: at the back of your mind
in the back of your mind
at the forefront of your mind

definitions.definition: your thoughts, interest, etc.

examples.text: **Keep your mind on** your work!
Your mind’s not on the job.
Her mind was completely occupied by the previous day's events.
The lecture dragged on and my mind wandered.
He **gave his mind to** the arrangements for the next day.
As for avoiding you, **nothing could be further from my mind** *(= I was not thinking of it at all)*.
My mind turned to more practical matters.
There's no stopping Elizabeth once she has her mind set on something.
Just free your mind and write whatever comes.
Her mind began to wander.
He occupied his mind by playing cards against himself.
His mind raced, trying to think of a way out of the situation.
Their own problems of course remained uppermost in their minds.

phrases: at the back of your mind
in the back of your mind
at the forefront of your mind

definitions.definition: your ability to remember things

examples.text: When I saw the exam questions my **mind** just **went blank** *(= I couldn't remember anything)*.
Sorry—your name has gone right out of my mind.
terrible images that will be imprinted on our minds forever

phrases: at the back of your mind
in the back of your mind
at the forefront of your mind

definitions.definition: if a thought, etc. is at the back of your mind, you are aware of it but it is not what you are mainly thinking about

examples.text: At the back of my mind was a small, warning voice, telling me it was wrong.
The problem was always at the back of my mind.

definitions.definition: to be something that only exists in somebody’s imagination

examples.text: These problems are all in your mind, you know.

definitions.definition: to remember somebody/something; to remember or consider that…

examples.text: You don't have to do anything about it now… just bear it in mind.
Here are some important points to keep in mind…
I'll keep what you say in mind.
Try to keep safety in the forefront of your mind at all times.

definitions.definition: to be extremely bored, etc.
if something is etched on your heart, memory, etc. you remember it because it has made a strong impression on you
if something is etched on your mind, heart, etc. you remember it because it has made a strong impression on you
to be unable to decide what you think about somebody/something, or whether to do something or not

examples.text: I was in two minds about the book *(= I didn't know if I liked it or not)*.
She's in two minds about accepting his invitation.

definitions.definition: to think very hard about one particular thing

examples.text: She bent her mind to the problem of escape.

definitions.definition: to think very hard about or put a lot of effort into one particular thing

examples.text: She bent her mind to the problem of escape.

definitions.definition: to have the same opinion about somebody/something
to be unable to think or behave in a reasonable way, especially because of extreme shock or worry

examples.text: You're lending them money? You must be out of your tiny mind!

definitions.definition: to be extremely worried, etc.
to produce a very strong feeling of pleasure or shock

examples.text: Wait till you hear this. It'll blow your mind.
a collection of photographs that will blow your mind

definitions.definition: if something boggles the mind or the mind boggles at it, it is so unusual that people find it hard to imagine or accept

examples.text: The vastness of space really boggles the mind.
‘He says he's married to his cats!’ ‘The mind boggles!’

definitions.definition: to remember somebody/something

examples.text: She couldn't call to mind where she had seen him before.

definitions.definition: to remind you of somebody/something

examples.text: The painting brings to mind some of Picasso's early works.

definitions.definition: to make yourself think about something that happened in the past

examples.text: I want you to cast your minds back to the first time you met.

definitions.definition: to change a decision or an opinion

examples.text: Nothing will make me change my mind.
What made you change your mind?

definitions.definition: an act of changing what you think about a situation, etc.
to refuse to think about something as a possibility
if something comes/springs to mind, you suddenly remember or think of it

examples.text: When discussing influential modern artists, three names immediately come to mind.
I'm sure someone can help you, but no one immediately springs to mind.

definitions.definition: to come into your mind

examples.text: It never crossed my mind that she might lose *(= I was sure that she would win)*.
The thought never crossed my mind!

definitions.definition: to tell somebody that you think their behaviour is bad or are angry with them
used to say that you and another person must both be very clever because you have had the same idea or agree about something
used to say that you think you will do something, although you are not sure

examples.text: I've half a mind to come with you tomorrow.

definitions.definition: used to say that you think that what somebody has done is bad and should do something about it, although you probably will not

examples.text: I've a good mind to write and tell your parents about it.

definitions.definition: to be thinking of somebody/something, especially for a particular job, etc.

examples.text: Do you have anyone in mind for this job?
Watching TV all evening wasn't exactly what I had in mind!
What kind of party do you have in mind?

definitions.definition: to intend to do something

examples.text: For a long time he had it in mind to write a novel about his experiences.

definitions.definition: to have a very bad memory; to forget things easily
to have your own opinion and make your own decisions without being influenced by other people

examples.text: She has a mind of her own and isn't afraid to say what she thinks.
My computer seems to have a mind of its own!

definitions.definition: to be willing to listen to or accept new ideas or suggestions

examples.text: Try to keep an open mind until you've heard all the facts.

definitions.definition: (not) thinking clearly; (not) able to make sensible decisions

examples.text: Who in their right mind would spend $50 000 on a pair of shoes?

definitions.definition: to have very clear and definite ideas about what you want to do
to become mentally ill

examples.text: He feared he was losing his mind.

definitions.definition: to decide something

examples.text: They're both beautiful—I can't make up my mind.
Have you made up your minds where to go for your honeymoon?
You'll never persuade him to stay—his **mind's made up** *(= he has definitely decided to go)*.
Come on—it's **make your mind up time**!

definitions.definition: a close understanding between people with similar ideas, especially when they meet to do something or meet for the first time

examples.text: a meeting of minds between the two artists

definitions.definition: the use of the power of your mind to deal with physical problems

examples.text: He said that keeping running in spite of the pain was just a question of mind over matter.

definitions.definition: your imagination

examples.text: He pictured the scene in his mind's eye.

definitions.definition: to give no attention to somebody/something

examples.text: People call him names sometimes, but he doesn't pay them any mind.

definitions.definition: not responsible for your actions because of a mental illness
if somebody/something is on your mind, you are thinking and worrying about them/it a lot

examples.text: You've been on my mind all day.
Don't bother your father tonight—he's **got a lot on his mind**.
a subject which was on the nation's collective mind
I have a lot on my mind at the moment.

definitions.definition: to become or make somebody aware of new ideas or experiences

examples.text: He’s eager to open the minds of his audience to different kinds of music.

definitions.definition: used to say somebody will quickly be forgotten when they are no longer with you
to make somebody think and worry about it all the time

examples.text: The thought that he could have helped more preyed on his mind.
It's been preying on my mind ever since it happened.

definitions.definition: to try to forget about something unpleasant

examples.text: I tried to push the thought to the back of my mind.

definitions.definition: to make somebody think of somebody/something; to remind somebody of somebody/something
to do or say something to make somebody stop worrying about something
to decide you want to achieve something and give this all your attention

examples.text: She could have been a brilliant pianist if she'd put her mind to it.
You can do whatever you set your mind to.

definitions.definition: to stop thinking about somebody/something; to deliberately forget somebody/something

examples.text: I just can't get her out of my mind.

definitions.definition: if something slips your mind, you forget it or forget to do it

examples.text: I’m sorry I didn’t tell you. It completely slipped my mind.

definitions.definition: to say exactly what you think, in a very direct way

examples.text: She’s never hesitated about speaking her mind.
Everyone should have the right to speak their mind.

definitions.definition: to be remembered for a long time

examples.text: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

definitions.definition: to make you forget about something unpleasant for a short time

examples.text: Painting helped take her mind off her troubles.

definitions.definition: in my opinion

examples.text: It was a ridiculous thing to do, to my mind.

definitions.definition: a particular way of thinking about things

wordOrigin: Old English gemynd ‘memory, thought’, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root meaning ‘revolve in the mind, think’, shared by Sanskrit manas and Latin mens ‘mind’.
